chatgpt_double_star.new_statement: Government should ensure everyone can obtain essential healthcare without risking medical bankruptcy, while letting people keep or purchase supplemental coverage if they want more options. A balanced approach sets a defined minimum benefit, caps out-of-pocket costs, and uses competition and negotiation to curb prices, reduce administrative waste, and reward quality outcomes. Implementation should strengthen primary care and mental health through local providers, with targeted help for rural areas and low-income families and clear public reporting so taxpayers can see results.

chatgpt_double_star_rankings.new_statement: Government should guarantee a universal, affordable baseline of high-quality healthcare—especially primary, preventive, mental-health, pediatric, and catastrophic protection—so no one faces medical bankruptcy and communities stay resilient. That public guarantee should come with strong cost controls, transparent pricing, streamlined enrollment, and outcome-based accountability to steward taxpayer funds. Care should be delivered through partnerships with local, rural, community, and faith-based providers, while preserving patient choice and room for private supplemental coverage and innovation.

chatgpt_double_star_personas.new_statement: Government should ensure every person can get a basic, affordable package of essential care—primary, preventive, mental-health, and emergency/catastrophic coverage—so no one faces medical bankruptcy or goes without needed treatment. The public role is to fund and coordinate that baseline, set clear rules for price transparency and quality, and reduce waste through simpler administration and accountable cost controls. Care should be delivered through a mix of local, rural, and community providers with protections for patient choice and space for private supplemental coverage and innovation, while targeting extra help to people with low incomes, disabilities, and high-cost conditions.
